ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: There is a classroom which Prof. Shin reserved for the course. I went in-person a few times and got to meet a few other students, which was nice. Mainly follows an onling / virtual structure.
Online office hours.
virtual seminar, student-led in class presentations, reading posts

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: How to read academic texts and how to take away the relevant points.
The main focus of this class was about the question, "What is a mathematical object, and do mathematical objects exist?"

I gained a lot of knowledge about the philosophical foundations of mathematics, along with the how the philosophy of mathematics has changed throughout history. I learned about Kant's philosophy of mathematics and how it relates to, or differs from, some of the major views during the late-19th and early-20th centuries -- notably, the views of Frege, Brouwer, and Hilbert. I also learned a lot about the historical epistemological and metaphysical arguments surrounding platonism and the nominalism (anti-platonism). We also covered some really interesting stuff at the end of the course about the role diagrams play in mathematics and mathematical beauty.
I was introduced to a wide spectrum of philosophical quandaries and viewpoints relating to mathematics, involving its epistemology, its ontology, and its values.

This course began by covering three philosophies of mathematics: logicism, intuitionism, and formalism. Then, we talked about arguments for and against realism. We also discussed the role of beauty in mathematics. The readings were all very interesting!
a survey understanding of the history of the philosophy of mathematics, and an introduction to meta questions in how the philosophy of mathematics is done as a whole

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course was amazing, only suggestion would be showing a timeline of all of the philosophies that were covered.

I really enjoyed short but thorough readings. Philosophical writing can be dense, and I appreciated about 30-40 pages per week, so that I could spend quite a while on each. The student-run seminars were a bit tedious. Professor Shin did a good job integrating her ideas, but I would have liked a mix of discussions led by students and led by her.

Sunjoo is incredible (as always). Writing the report for each weekly class was definitely a huge strength. The reading was manageable enough to let us really spend a good amount of time understanding, and the report somehow really aided in comprehension.

I found the format of class very helpful in understanding the arguments in the text while still getting to have some really fun conversations about it. Students present the material during one class; this is very helpful because it causes students to become more familiar with a certain part of the course, which helps students find possible paper topics and become better thinkers.

Having every student lead a particular seminar each week was a unique way to keep the class engaging. It did feel that we rushed through a lot of material, without going too in-depth with any particular topic (outside of the research paper)

Prof. Shin is a great teacher and the course covers really fascinating material.  But the structure of presentations every week and little discussion made it in my opinion less productive than it could have been had we gotten either more lecturing from the professor or more seminar discussion.

The material covered in the course and Professor Shin's comments were great. I think the course could be improved by having more discussion between students. This was hard this semester, given that class was online.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Discussions and presentations over Zoom worked very well.
Having the students present information on the weekly readings was an innovative tool, and having us write weekly reports on what we read kept us accountable for the readings.
the student-led in-class presentations really kept everybody engaged and doing the readings

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Incredible class that gave me a sense of the greatest minds in mathematics and philosophy. Most of the workload involves reading a paper once a week and discussing it in class. These papers range from the 1700s to the 1960s and were mostly really easy to follow and discuss. The seminar format really optimized learning while not requiring a great deal of outside work. That being said, the final 15 page paper was difficult and I hope the grading will be fair. I got the majority of it done over Thanksgiving and would I highly recommend getting an early start. Prof. Shin is amazing and is willing to work with students in crafting their argument, and the personal feedback we received on the weekly reading reports was very much appreciated.

Yes, though I will note that it is an upper-level seminar, and should be treated as such. As somewhat of a beginner in the discipline, there were moments I was confused and a bit intimidated to ask questions.
Yes, definitely. You should take any course offered by Sunjoo. This class was a great introduction to the philosophy of mathematics, and I believe that the topics covered are pretty canonical.

Absolutely! If you like math and like thinking about the more philosophical side of things, this course is for you. The material is super interesting and will probably change how you think about mathematics. Professor Shin is very kind and knows all about the subjects covered. She makes the discussions fun and provides a lot of useful, and interesting, insights into the material. Some of the material may be a bit hard to understand at first if you aren't already familiar with general philosophy terminology, e.g. "epistemological," "ontological," etc. Familiarity with mathematical proofs is not necessarily needed but will make you appreciate the content more and will make some of the arguments easier to follow. Overall, if you like logic and math, take this course because it is very fun.
If you are interested in this particular subject, and you have studied set theory and know what this course is going to be about, it's pretty good.
I would recommend this course to other students, especially if they are interested in the more epistemological side of mathematics, and how we understand it.

Absolutely i would recommend this course (as well as any course with Prof. Shin)! But be prepared to learn a lot about whichever topics you choose to write about and present about, and understand that for weeks where presentations are subpar you will get a lot less out of the class.

Professor Shin is an amazing teacher, and the material covered in this course is very interesting. The topics we covered in mathematical foundations should be of interest to anyone studying logic, philosophy of science, epistemology, or math. The readings were incredible, and Professor Shin does a great job of explaining the material.
of course! Professor Shin is phenomenal and this class is a great introduction to many foundational concepts in the philosophy of mathematics
